Hi @leh-ppi,

I don't think a wholesale replace to relative symlinks is the way to go here (`tar.go` is used elsewhere than just for OCI). Can you explain what you're looking to achieve using symlinks within the OCI artifact?

It is _super_ important that when the manifests have been extracted from the OCI artifact that there are not any symlinks that can break outside of the directory where the manifests have been extracted to. I'm pretty sure that this would still be the case even with this PR, but I (and presumably other maintainers) would want extra assurances that this is still the case - so at a minimum tests would need to be added to assert that fact.
This LGTM, I'd like to get another pair of eyes on this (@crenshaw-dev or @leoluz) just to verify that this is a reasonable change.
Please fix the failing checks.
@RajatPorwal5, thanks for contributing the doc extension. Please take a look at the suggested improvements. I find this a good addition in general, albeit somewhat repetitive and lengthy.

afk this week, just doing a quick review by phone. Can you add docs explaining

1) that the path is required
2) that app paths get cleaned per hydration
3) that the root dir doesn't get cleaned per hydration 
4) that app paths dont get cleaned up when paths change or apps are removed
5) a quick explanation for why the feature exists (preserving CI files)

And also a release note explaining that we're making a breaking path to require non-root paths, how to find affected apps, and how to migrate (including any cleanup steps, like removing a leftover manifest.yaml and README.md from the root).

Final (small) thing is that, if its not already there, we should add kubebuilder validation to the path field making it required with a required length greater than zero.

With this solution seems there is a possibility that we run into a stuck deletion 
`   Error: "Forbidden: no new finalizers can be added if the object is being deleted"`
One user described it here:
https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/17433#issuecomment-2937807562

Looks like they worked around it by using `config.preserve: false` but not all charts may have this and run into the stuck deletion issue.

If this is not a big concern, we should document somewhere about the required Kyverno config `config.preserve: false` so users know how to workaround the deletion issue

What do you think?

Looks like the package "github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/aws" is deprecated with the release, See https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/pull/5350/files. Should we move to `aws-sdk-go-v2` with this upgrade or wait to upgrade to the next minor release?

I have mixed feelings about this scope. On one hand, "CLI expert" might be an unusual qualification, and we might not often find people to fit this role. On the other hand, I think as long as we do have people who would fit this role, it makes sense to unblock their work.

tl;dr, generally in favor but want to hear other's thoughts!

I believe this is missing the generated doc code for CLI.

but LGTM for the scoped approver. 

This will allow a faster approval process for cleanup, refactors and general maintenance PRs

I'm not too sure if CLI scoped approve will be really effective. As @todaywasawesome  shared from a recent report, there are very little amount of PRs created only updating code in the CLI folder. It was also pointed out that changes in the CLI also requires a doc update. Besides the effectiveness issue I believe that this will potentially contribute to future bad code design. For example: if 2 members from the same org are working on a CLI feature and they only have permission to merge in the cli folder, they could be inclined to only add code this directory which would contribute to code duplication and promote bad design decisions.
can we write tests to verify this?
LGTM!

I'm really cautious of special carve-outs when it comes to security issues. Giving special meaning to a `*/*` glob or a regex matching `*/*` that casbin doesn't have seems like it risks future mistakes and misunderstandings. 

I'd propose that we instead drop the enumeration protections in 4.0 and clarify in docs that we only offer soft tenancy and don't protect against app enumeration by authenticated users.

Overall LGTM but there are few things we need to consider IMHO
Is this PR ready for review? I only see one test case.

You're required to add all the test cases that checks these scenarios:
- Resource should be pruned when --prune and missing from backup
- Resource should be created when missing from live
- Resource tracking annotation should not be updated when --ignore-tracking
- Application operation should removed when --stop-operation
- Update operation should retry on conflict when --override-on-conflict
- Resource should not be pruned if present in backup and backup resource matches --skip-resources-with-label
- Resource should not be pruned if missing from backup, but live matches --skip-resources-with-label
- Test application-namespace feature
- Test applicationset-namespace feature
- Dry run should not modify any resources

I like the structure of the tests, but reading a few different scenario names, I am not sure what it is actually testing. For instance, "It should update the live object according to the backup object if the backup object doesn't have the skip label". This test the happy path. where is the test that validates that it should **not** update the resource when it matches the label?

Similar comment for the following tests, they seem to all be testing the happy path, and not the conditional scenarios
- "Spec should be updated correctly in live object according to the backup object"
- "It should update the data of the live object according to the backup object"
- "It should update live object's spec according to the backup object"
Is this PR ready for review? Once ready, please remove it from draft.

Thank you for spending time working on it (especially on weekends, really appreciate that). Please do the following things:

1. Provide a better test case name. For example, a test case name such as `It should update live object if skip label is not present in backup object` doesn't make more sense. 
2. Impotant: I see you're copying the content of the `backup.go` file and using the exact code in the test case. There's no harm but I think that's an example of bad code. I'd suggest you refactor the code for import command in the `backup.go` file, create separate functions for usability and call those functions instead for your unit tests. This makes sure that everything is tested correctly. For example, instead of copying the logic for  how the keys are getting added to map, create a separate function that put the keys in the map based on the resource type, call that function in the test case. Now, you're not only checking the correct behaviour of the import command but also making sure that the map handling is working correctly as required. 

Let me know if you have any questions. Thanks!


I think this has to be reworked to update on each regular refresh and/or refresh triggered by webhook or something else, but it shouldn't trigger new refreshes due to perf reasons. We may need another field refreshedAt if not present.

One other risk we should consider: If the user can define any `baseUrl` in their plugin ConfigMap, they can use a plugin generator to map all services available in the cluster. We should consider allowing the Argo CD admin to set some kind of URL allowlist for plugins.

Thanks for your PR.

I tend to think that giving users control over the refresh time would not be a good idea, as this will put unexpected strain on the application controller and repository server - especially in the case of a hard refresh.

I'm also not sure yet whether a setting such as this should be an annotation, or whether it is better housed in the spec.

IMHO, we should think this through, and come up with a proper way to allow/disallow users from actually leveraging this setting (e.g. by having a flag in the AppProject).

TL;DR: I think this needs further discussion.

I also think this needs further discussion. I agree with @jannfis on the different arguments above. Argo CD is a GitOps tool and react to git changes.

I think if there is a need to monitor an external non-git systems, like an artifact registry to detect non-gitops changes, this can be done by another controller. Then that controller can request a refresh of the application with the current annotation/api when it detects changes that would require a refresh. A naive implementation would be to do it periodically

Thanks for the clarification about the problem, I reproduced it.
In the existing code, the additional fields that exist in the wide output do not exist on the original struct of SyncWindows, so they are not present upon json/yaml marshaling.
So it definitely makes sense to add them explicitly.
The problem with this suggestion is that if a new field would be added/changed to SyncWindows in the future, someone would have to add/change it to collectSyncWindowData as well .
This can be solved by unmarshalling the original struct to a map and then just adding the extra fields, instead of populating all the fields one by one.
This needs more discussion.

https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/pull/18453

This error indicates that there is a mismatch between the labels used in With and the labels used in the Vec, and indeed the vectors do not have the "dest_cluster" label.

But there are a couple of other things to consider first:
- Maybe the existing dest_server metric is enough?
- The "name" and "server" fields on the Application destination spec are mutually exclusive: https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/blob/master/pkg/apis/application/v1alpha1/types.go#L989
   So both can't exist on an App, maybe the vectors should contain either dest_name or dest_server according to what is specified in the Application, if so, a new set of Apps with destination name instead of destination cluster would be probably needed for testing.
- If the new metric is relevant, I think that for compatibility with naming convention of the existing dest_namespace and dest_server, it should be called dest_name instead of cluster_name.

The PR is pretty large. I suggest breaking it the following way:
* Separate Cluster, MachineDeployment and KubeadmControlPlane.
* Separate modifications of existing checks from adding new checks.
As commented, maybe use 2.9.9 and rebase.
I think this could benefit from more description about the problem this tries to solve. Can you open an issue, please?

@rolandkool I don't think this is correct. By default Argo CD checks for changes to the repo every 3 minutes, if there are no changes to the repo the cache is still invalidated after 24 hours. So for example, if you have a helm chart that generates a random value, that will be picked up every 24 hours but because no files change, not before.

The scenario you've laid out the files are changing and are not being picked up.
LGTM
Thanks! Can you rebase just in case, please?

I think it'd be easier to manage and work with if we split config maps by roles or something like this.

An explicit allowlist of extra cm-s in one of main cm-s sounds safer than just label, which people can add to arbitrary cm.

We may hit some race conditions when updating multiple files. Let's introduce some kind of version field and require a consistent value of it from all involved cm-s to actually combine the data.
Why do we copy a ujson instead of using its package and importing it? This essentially creates a fork we'd have to maintain.

I would prefer this to be implemented in another way, instead of (yet another) undocumented environment variable.

Two options that come to my mind:

1) A command line flag for the application controller or
2) Move the setting to the AppProject level

I was wondering whether it makes more sense to introduce a real health check under a more "formal" path like `/healthz`?

I just took a look and indeed the applicationset controller does not yet have one (and therefore, also no readyness or liveness probes in the deployment).

Maybe it's time to build one?

Hi, and thanks for offering this contribution.

I have taken a look, and it seems that while the plugin itself is open source, the backend would be paid-only and proprietary. If this is the case, I hope for your understanding that I'll tend to refrain from including it in our documentation.

It's not 1:1 conversion, e.g. FORCE_LOG_COLORS is missing.

Great progress with the proposal and I think that this is going in a good direction.
There are a few existing Argo CD features that will be likely impacted by this proposal and needs to be considered:

- managedFieldsManagers: There is a feature in Argo CD that allows ignoring differences in state owned by a different managers (See https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user-guide/diffing/ search by `managedFieldsManagers`). We need to validate if the existing feature will be compatible with the changes suggested in this proposal. If not, proper direction needs to be given.
- Managed namespaces feature uses SSA behind the scenes. We need to state that this proposal needs to be compatible with the existing feature (see https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user-guide/sync-options/#namespace-metadata)
- Feature flag: We need to implement this new feature behind a feature flag (Sync Option) that could be enabled at the controller lever as well as at the application level.

We don't need to deep dive in those features during the proposal phase but this is something that absolutely needs to be worked on and well tested during the implementation.

Please add the scenarios above in the use-cases section of this proposal with a brief explanation about how we are going to solve them.
Please update the proposal adding the requirement to make the resource tracking logic for labels and annotation support multiple Apps owning the same resource.

@pdostal The issue here is that the example configuration actually supports GRPC, GRPCS, and HTTP. By setting the backend-protocol in this way, you essentially are disabling support for these other protocols. The SSL-passthrough documentation actually explains this above. 

You might add a note in the documentation to suggest setting this in some scenarios but as is, I don't think it can be merged.

Thanks for this PR. It does look good, but I have some concerns. 

Actually, this PR duplicates a lot of code from the Application stream, which I think is not a good thing to do. It increases maintenance substantially, and introduces a lot of redundancy.

I think it would be good to find some common ground between the Application and ApplicationSet broadcaster and streaming functionality to reduce redundancy.

Thanks @gczuczy for the fix. I am not an expert on CMP, but the changes look good to me!!

@leoluz @crenshaw-dev can you take a look at the PR too?

I am not sure if making a CMP with no stdout to be considered an error is a good idea. I imagine that not generating any output is a valid use-case for some plugins that would generate manifests in some cases but not in others. This would be even more appealing use-case for multi-source applications that generate part of the manifests statically and part relying on a plugin.

The problem identified in https://github.com/argoproj/argo-cd/issues/15339 is valid and should be addressed by the plugin itself by correctly using `set -o pipefail` as part of the script.

I'm not sure if I'd agree with this change. What value has ignoring unknown flags? From a user experience perspective, throwing an error on unknown flags is a good thing to do imho. It also prevents accidentally missing an important flag on a subtle typo.

Hi @denysvitali, thanks a lot for trying to tackle this issue and for your patience. There's a lot of PR backlog right now, we're very sorry about the delay. 

I have a few concerns with this PR as-is, because as far as I can tell, it makes the cluster name a mandatory field. If this assumption is correct, it means that the PR will introduce a majorly breaking change, because the cluster name is currently an optional property of any cluster connection and may not be set in many configurations.

Also, what effects will this have on the cluster cache? Currently, we use the cluster's URL as the primary key for cluster caches. I have not seen a change to this logic in the PR, so I assume that this still holds true. Because many of the cluster settings are defined within the cluster cache, I have the concern that this ends up in a scenario where we have multiple clusters with the same URL but a different name, but only a single cluster cache configuration?
